nodes.text: Absolute income mobility in the United States has declined since 1940, and this decline can be explained by changes in GDP growth and the distribution of growth

We estimate rates of absolute income mobility (fraction of children earning more than their parents) by combining marginal income distributions for parents and children with the copula of parent and child income ranks

Baseline measurement: family pretax income at age 30 measured in 2014 dollars using CPI-U-RS; parents and children marginal distributions from decennial Census IPUMS and CPS; copula from de-identified tax records for 1980-1982 cohorts

Where historical panel copula data are unavailable, assume copula stability from 1940 or compute tight upper and lower bounds by solving a linear program over all copulas satisfying first-order stochastic dominance constraints

Assumption: children and parents income ranks are comparable over time; exclude immigrants post-1994 and exclude parents with zero/negative income when estimating copula (assigning those children's mobility = 100%)
Result: Under copula stability benchmark, average absolute mobility fell from 92% for the 1940 birth cohort to 50% for the 1984 cohort (measured at age 30)

Result: Bounds analysis relaxing copula stability yields tight bounds for early cohorts (e.g., 1940 cohort bounded 84% to 98%) and wide bounds for recent cohorts, but still implies a sharp decline in absolute mobility since 1940

Method detail: construct parent income distributions by pooling decennial censuses, selecting parents by child ages and parent ages around 30, and compute child distributions from CPS March supplements
Evidence: Overlap between parent and child marginal income distributions is small for 1940 cohort (explaining tight bounds) and large for 1980 cohort (explaining sensitivity to copula)

Claim: The decline in absolute mobility is largest in the middle and upper parts of the income distribution and occurred across all states and both sexes (with different patterns when measuring individual earnings)

Sensitivity results: findings are robust to alternative price deflators, tax and transfer adjustments, measuring income at age 40, family-size adjustments, measuring individual instead of family income, and plausible upward adjustments to reported child incomes

Counterfactual simulation method: reallocate GDP across percentiles or change GDP per working-age family growth to construct counterfactual child marginal distributions and recompute absolute mobility using observed copula and parent marginals

Result (higher GDP growth counterfactual): If 1980 cohort had experienced mid-century higher GDP growth (2.5% per family) but the 2010 distribution of income shares, absolute mobility for 1980 cohort would rise to about 62% (partial recovery)

Result (more broadly shared growth counterfactual): If 1980 cohort experienced actual GDP but income shares as in 1940 cohort, absolute mobility would rise to about 80%, reversing over 70% of the decline

Conclusion: Reviving mid-century levels of absolute mobility requires that economic growth be shared more broadly across the income distribution; higher aggregate growth alone is insufficient under current distributional shares
